docs.abstract: Google Home and Amazon Echo don’t carry paid advertising, so companies are trying more creative ways of using them to reach consumers.
docs.snippet: Google Home and Amazon Echo don’t carry paid advertising, so companies are trying more creative ways of using them to reach consumers.
docs.lead_paragraph: Heading into last year’s holidays, marketers at HBO were eagerly experimenting with how to use technology like augmented reality and virtual reality to promote their shows. But then, celebrating with their families across the country, they watched as everyone from children to elderly aunts unwrapped smart speakers from Google and Amazon and started barking orders.

headline.main: Marketing Through Smart Speakers? Brands Don’t Need to Be Asked Twice
headline.print_headline: Marketing via Alexa? Brands Are Speaking Up

docs.abstract: The Bay Area in California remains the nation’s high-tech epicenter. But New York’s tech work force has been growing impressively.
docs.snippet: The Bay Area in California remains the nation’s high-tech epicenter. But New York’s tech work force has been growing impressively.
docs.lead_paragraph: In 2003, Craig Nevill-Manning, a computer scientist at Google, wanted to set up an engineering outpost in New York. Google’s top leaders were skeptical, but they told him that he could go ahead if he could find 15 “Google-worthy” software developers in the city.

headline.main: New York Is a Genuine Tech Hub (and That Was Before Amazon)
headline.print_headline: New York Matures as a Hub for Technology

docs.abstract: Is it O.K. to shop on Amazon for everything and still not want one of the world’s richest companies to invade Queens?
docs.snippet: Is it O.K. to shop on Amazon for everything and still not want one of the world’s richest companies to invade Queens?
docs.lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start your day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

docs.abstract: The e-commerce giant, while mulling 20 finalists for its second headquarters, has kept up a “blistering” pace of expansion for technology jobs and fulfillment centers.
docs.snippet: The e-commerce giant, while mulling 20 finalists for its second headquarters, has kept up a “blistering” pace of expansion for technology jobs and fulfillment centers.
docs.lead_paragraph: As Amazon dances through courtship rituals with the 20 cities hoping to host its second headquarters, the company is also charging ahead on a slate of other real estate projects.

headline.main: Amazon, Not Waiting for HQ2, Announces Projects in Boston and Vancouver
headline.print_headline: Amazon Projects on ‘Blistering Pace’ As Cities Await Word on New Campus

docs.abstract: The president has often taken to Twitter to criticize companies, but investors don’t appear to be taking the attacks too seriously.
docs.snippet: The president has often taken to Twitter to criticize companies, but investors don’t appear to be taking the attacks too seriously.
docs.lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline.main: Trump’s Thumps Don’t Cause Stock Slumps
headline.print_headline: Trump’s Broadsides Against Companies Barely Register on Wall Street

docs.abstract: We claim to want it, companies claim to provide it, but we all just accept that, well, you have no privacy online.
docs.snippet: We claim to want it, companies claim to provide it, but we all just accept that, well, you have no privacy online.
docs.lead_paragraph: We claim to want it, companies claim to provide it, but we all just accept that, well, you have no privacy online.

headline.main: It’s Time to Panic About Privacy

docs.abstract: Amazon and Google are aggressively opening offices outside of their Silicon Valley and Seattle hometowns. On Thursday, Apple said it would invest $1 billion in Austin, Tex.
docs.snippet: Amazon and Google are aggressively opening offices outside of their Silicon Valley and Seattle hometowns. On Thursday, Apple said it would invest $1 billion in Austin, Tex.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — This generation’s biggest technology companies — including Apple, Amazon and Google — have long been tied to their hometowns. Now these giants are increasingly outgrowing their West Coast roots.

headline.main: Chase for Talent Pushes Tech Giants Far Beyond West Coast
headline.print_headline: Craving Talent and Growth, Tech Giants Go East

byline.original: By Jack Nicas and Karen Weise

docs.abstract: Steve Case has been on the road with J.D. Vance, the author of “Hillbilly Elegy,” to promote entrepreneurship across the United States.
docs.snippet: Steve Case has been on the road with J.D. Vance, the author of “Hillbilly Elegy,” to promote entrepreneurship across the United States.
docs.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Steve Case has been on a barnstorming tour of the United States in a red bus that reads “The Rise of the Rest.” You would be forgiven for thinking he was running for office.

headline.main: The Effort to Reimagine Company Towns

docs.abstract: There are nations and industries in sound economic shape that are ignored by investors because they are not all about tech. Maybe that is about to change.
docs.snippet: There are nations and industries in sound economic shape that are ignored by investors because they are not all about tech. Maybe that is about to change.
docs.lead_paragraph: After a decade of extraordinary gains, the American stock market has come unhinged in recent weeks, with the technology sector leading the rapid decline. American tech giants are down on average 25 percent from recent peaks, and it appears the big global bubble of the 2010s is bursting. The question on everyone’s mind is what comes next.

headline.main: When the Bubble Bursts, Consider the Anti-Bubble
headline.print_headline: The Tech Bubble May Be Bursting

docs.abstract: The company had long struggled to gain traction in China despite operating there for more than a decade.
docs.snippet: The company had long struggled to gain traction in China despite operating there for more than a decade.
docs.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon may dominate online shopping in the United States, but in the world’s second-largest economy it is all but calling it quits.

headline.main: Amazon Gives Up on Chinese Domestic Shopping Business
headline.print_headline: Amazon Backs Away From China As Years of Sales Prove Lackluster
